summary: This document is an email chain from May 2020 between US Attorney's Office (SDNY) prosecutors, FBI personnel, and contractors regarding the processing and transfer of digital evidence seized from Jeffrey Epstein's properties. It details significant logistical challenges, data management issues, and coordination problems in handling the massive volume of evidence from search warrants executed at Epstein's New York mansion and US Virgin Islands residence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the investigation; digital evidence was seized from his residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands.

events.title: Coordination on Epstein evidence transfer
events.description: Email chain discussing plans to transfer digital evidence from seized devices to the US Attorney's Office for review, including use of a spreadsheet template.

events.title: Conference call scheduled
events.description: Planning of a conference call to discuss issues with the Epstein search warrant evidence and data transfer.

events.title: Significant data review problems reported
events.description: Prosecutors report major problems reviewing over 1 million documents received, including inability to link emails with attachments and mismatched load files.

events.title: Listing of evidence provided
events.description: Forensic examiner provides listing of what has been handed over from Epstein searches, noting 9 IDE hard drives from Manhattan apartment were copies of 3 drives from a July 2007 search.

events.title: Evidence tracking confusion
events.description: Prosecutor reports confusion over what evidence is new vs. previously received, with over 600,000 items in one folder and no clear labeling system.

locations: Island (likely referring to Little St. James, Epstein's private island)
keyFacts: Digital evidence was seized from Epstein's residences in New York and the US Virgin Islands, including approximately 40+ devices from New York and more than 25 devices from the Virgin Islands.

Prosecutors reported significant problems reviewing over 1 million documents, including inability to link emails with attachments and mismatched load files that made many files 'completely invisible'.
Nine IDE hard drives found in Epstein's Manhattan apartment were determined to be three copies of three drives from a July 2007 search on one of his properties.
The evidence included CDs from the New York search that contained only pictures (no documents), and forensic examiners were still working on processing Apple/Mac items.
Coordination challenges were exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic, with forensic examiners reduced to one day per week of work, stretching timelines by a factor of five.
